content: OK, I honestly would like to see a version of this as a normal puzzle, with the removed last testcase or even bigger ranges and tests that require logarithmic algo.
Edited to remove the last testcase (N = 10^6) to conform to the new official "Contribution Guidelines".
I did come up with a solution using bitwise operators that was able to pass the final test.   But I'm still in the opinion that this is too hard for CoC.
The solution is too tight to come up with and code in 5 minutes.
Not so easy to come up with for me, but I think doable in a given timeframe.
Clear instructions. I am keened to seeing this match in shortest mode. There is likely a mathematics way of solving this :))

Very simple. If anything I would give states for each coin, (something like "X coins are heads and Y coins are tails"). Overall would work fine for a clash. 

Hopefully there aren't any duplicates.
On the second thought, 5 minutes is too tight for this to solve...

Are you sure? I don't mean any offense but this puzzle seemed fairly easy to solve, at least for me personally. Do you think the question was poorly worded? Did you eventually get the solution figured out?

What do you mean exactly? Are you talking about a O(R-L) approach per query (i.e. O(N^2) solution overall)?

Because you are expected to find a roughly O(N) (neglecting Q as Q<<N here) approach to pass the last test. The solution below gives two such approaches. But this can actually even be solved in O(Q log Q) (improving the loop on N in the second approach). There are lots of different efficient approaches!

The naive O(N^2) approach might pass, in a fast language, when optimized by xoring bitstrings (this basically reduces N by a factor 32 or 64) but, well, fair enough as this is more tedious anyway.

EDIT: Last testcase removed. The naive O(N^2) approach will pass from now on.

I sort of agree with Tarapitha. 

The last test case was a bit pain in the ass for me. But once you know the trick, the problem is fairly easy.

I think this should belong to easy puzzle section. I first tried the raw approach, but of course the 10^6 coins test did not pass, it took already one minute to understand the statement, come up with preliminary solution and code it. Then I had to come up with alternative approach and all of it together was longer than 5 minutes. I took no offence, I'm not a software developer, I just like coding :)

MSWS, you really did a 10^6 solution no problem? I have a hard time believing anyone would come up with an off the cuff  solution that can figure out a way to mark the beginning and end of the flips and sum the final results.

It was pretty easy to write a solution that stored all the coin positions and flips all them in the range but of course that fails the last test because of timeout. 

Then I had to study the given solution for a while to understand how they were able to track all the flips, which the method is way outside the normal solution process for a problem.    So I call B.S. on your idea that this is solved super easily and everyone should get it in a couple of minutes.  I bet you the success rate on this will be under 5% within the 15 minutes, probably even lower than that.

Hello theplen, it looks like you are answering to my comment, but your content is disputing things that I have not written and that are not there. This CoC is already approved, but I still think that placing this puzzle under easy puzzle section would have been better idea, because as I wrote earlier, I run out of CoC time limit while coming up with the solution.

I was attempting to reply to MSWS's reply to your post.  But it looks like the replies only thread to two levels.  I agree with your statement that this is to hard for CoC.  I think very few people will be able to come up with a 10^6 solution in under 15 minutes.

Uh... yeah... Sorry, didn't meant to sound condescending or anything...

My solution was extremely simple, maybe it was just a fluke of Java?

https://pastebin.com/bQi1YXHz

@MSWS, yeah that is the same exact solution I wrote in Ruby and it timed out on the last test.  Goes to prove how much faster Java is than most scripting languages (Ruby, Python, PHP).

In the scripting languages you have to use a special method of marking the beginning and end of each range L = +=1, R+1 -= 1 and when you sum it up you can infer that the coins in between are the same as the start of the range.  Or I did find that I was able to beat the timeout by using bitwise operators.
@MSWS, nice at least I know Java solution passes with O(n^2) appproach :D
